result.execSummary:
The defendant Mackenzie L. Schultz was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manuf/Deliver Amphetamine(<=3g), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(e)1.
  • Possession of Methamphetamine, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(g).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Balance of bond on 16CF151 applied.  Balance due to Agent.

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due, and/or other collection means, such as income assignment will be issued.The Defendant is to complete an AODA assessment and comply with any treatment recommended.  The Defendant is to undergo any counseling the agent finds appropriate and must comply with any recommended treatment/assessment/counseling.  Defendant may not withdraw from any ordered program without permission of the agent and/or provider.  The Defendant is to abide by all rules and conditions of the Agent.  The Defendant is to maintain absolute sobriety - no alcohol or drugs unless prescribed by a physician.  The Defendant is subject to observed random drug/UA testing.  The Defendant is to obtain and maintain full time employment after a reasonable maternity leave.  The Defendant is to have no contact with known drug dealers or drug users.  Contact with B.K. only as approved by the Agent.  The Defendant is to provide a biological specimen for DNA analysis within 60 days.   After 2 years, if all conditions are met, and Agent recommends, the Court will approve early termination of probation.
